awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Rational Design of Alloys with Low-Melting-Point Metals for High-yield, Non-thermal Plasma-assisted Catalytic Production of Ammonia
awd_abstract_narration:
Close to 2% of the world's energy is spent synthesizing ammonia by a chemical process called the Haber-Bosch process.  Plasma catalysis is emerging as a promising alternative method for ammonia synthesis at moderate pressure and temperature, which allows it to rely on renewable energy resources that are more distributed and intermittent in nature. The goal of the proposed collaborative research project is to use computation and experiment to rationally design an alloy catalyst for a new plasma-assisted ammonia synthesis process that requires less energy. The research will also train students from underrepresented and minority groups and support the development and dissemination of educational materials on a general access website.

The project will integrate experiments and simulations in a feedback loop that will culminate with the computational identification of a high-performance low melting point alloy that will be tested in catalytic experiments under an atmospheric plasma.  The fundamental reaction mechanisms under plasma conditions will be elucidated by using kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. The research objectives of the project are: (1) Synthesize gallium alloys and evaluate kinetics of ammonia synthesis in a radio-frequency plasma reactor. (2) Determine recombination kinetics of H and N radicals from "plasma-on-plasma-off" experiments. (3) Calculate energetic descriptors for ammonia synthesis reaction steps under plasma conditions using Density Functional Theory. (4) Develop a kinetic Monte-Carlo model for ammonia formation using graph theoretical approach and cluster expansion. (5) Experimentally test a computationally identified alloy in a plasma reactor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ammonia (NH3) is used as precursor for fertilizers, but its synthesis produces close to 2% of the world’s CO2 emissions. Therefore, there is a critical need to decarbonize ammonia synthesis to simultaneously meet food and climate sustainability goals. The key for this decarbonization is a mild synthesis process that can be powered with renewable electricity and allows the use of green hydrogen as feed.

The scientific goals of this collaborative project were to first provide knowledge on how ammonia forms from nitrogen (N2) and hydrogen (H2) using plasma catalysis, which is an attractive alternative for mild synthesis.  Then, to leverage this knowledge to develop materials and/or reactor configurations that could improve the energy efficiency of the process, with the purpose of pushing towards the threshold for economic feasibility.

Computational work on this project first used quantum mechanics calculations to elucidate the energy barriers for the elementary reaction steps potentially involved in the formation of ammonia over a catalyst under a plasma environment. The calculations revealed that new reaction routes involving N2HY species that are not considered in standard ammonia synthesis were plausible, due to negligible energy barriers for reaction steps involving the collision of N and H plasma radicals with species adsorbed on the catalyst (Fig. 1).     

Then this project used (micro)kinetic modeling, informed by the above obtained energy barriers, to predict what the ammonia formation rate trends would be across different metals under different plasma compositions (Fig. 2a). By finding the conditions that led to agreement between predicted and experimentally observed trends, clarity was provided to the ongoing debate whether the kinetics-controlling species are N and H plasma radicals or vibrationally excited N2.

This project provided, arguably conclusive, support for N and H plasma radical as controlling species by demonstrating its necessary involvement to explain experimental observations such as: i) a weak dependence of ammonia formation rate on catalyst chemistry in the plasma assisted process (even when including metals considered inactive for standard ammonia synthesis), Fig. 2b, ii) the improved ammonia formation rate on iron when the process switches from thermal to plasma catalysis (Fig. 2c).    

Despite the weak dependence of ammonia formation rate on catalyst chemistry, this project did provide empirical descriptors of catalyst performance. Specifically, it was found that the ammonia formation rate across three sets of experiments in various types of plasma reactors correlates strongly with the reaction energy for the step that converts adsorbed HNNH2 to HNNH3 through collision with an H plasma radical (Fig. 3). A weaker (inverse) correlation was found between ammonia formation rate and the strength of N adsorption.

The weaker (and easier to calculate) descriptor was used to prescreen a database of ~2000 metal alloys, from which a subset of metals with weaker N adsorption was identified, and for which the more accurate descriptor was calculated (Fig. 4a). Ultimately, three potential compositions were identified that according to the descriptor should yield better catalytic performance than the incumbent best metal according to experiments to date, i.e., gold (Fig. 4b). 

But as the ammonia formation rate is only weakly dependent on catalyst chemistry, this project also explored materials for alternative ways to improve energy yields centered on the idea of preventing the unintended destruction of recently formed ammonia by the plasma. Two strategies (informed by work by the experimental partner of this project) involving nanoporous materials with high affinity for ammonia were considered. One where the porous material also has catalytic activity, but where the newly formed ammonia is retained and protected from destruction, with the product released periodically when the plasma is off. Another one where the porous material is used as a membrane that continuously flushes out newly formed ammonia from the reactor.

With the aid of machine learning and molecular simulation, a database of ~10,000 metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) was screened for the two abovementioned strategies, resulting in the identification of a subset of MOFs with potentially better affinity, selectivity, and capacity for ammonia than other materials that have been experimentally tested by the experimental partner (e.g., Ni-MOF-74 as a porous catalyst, and CC3 as a porous membrane). Additionally, the ideal properties a material should have for this application emerged from the screening data (Fig. 5). 

Significant findings on ammonia formation, adsorption and release mechanisms were published in three papers, and an additional paper on porous material screening results is being currently written. Aligned with broader impact goals, this project involved the training of two grad, three undergrad, and four high school students, with six of them belonging to underrepresented groups and/or minorities. This project also generated material to develop a course partly focused on computational development of catalyst, including and assignment where students used data from quantum mechanics calculation and microkinetic modeling to screen metal catalysts for (traditional) ammonia synthesis.
